canonical_explanation.text: Our environment is everything around us - the air, water, land, plants, animals, and all living and non-living things. We must keep our surroundings clean and healthy. Dirty surroundings attract flies, mosquitoes, and rats, which spread diseases. Waste is of two types: wet waste (like food scraps and vegetable peels, which can decompose) and dry waste (like plastic, glass, and metal, which do not decompose easily). We can help the environment by following the 3Rs: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use things again), and Recycle (make new things from old materials). We should plant trees, use dustbins, and keep our school, home, and neighbourhood clean.
rules: Our environment includes all living and non-living things around us
Clean surroundings prevent diseases spread by flies, mosquitoes, and rats
Wet waste (biodegradable): food scraps, vegetable peels, leaves - can decompose naturally
Dry waste (non-biodegradable): plastic, glass, metal, rubber - does not decompose easily
3Rs: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), Recycle (make new from old)
We should use dustbins, plant trees, and avoid littering

questions.question_text: Why should we keep our surroundings clean?

options.text: To prevent diseases caused by flies, mosquitoes, and germs
It does not matter if surroundings are dirty

questions.explanation_correct: We should keep our surroundings clean to prevent diseases. Dirty places attract flies, mosquitoes, cockroaches, and rats, which carry germs that can make us sick. Clean surroundings help us stay healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Keeping our surroundings clean is not just because a teacher said so. The real reason is that dirty places become breeding grounds for disease-carrying insects and pests. Flies sit on garbage and then on our food, spreading germs.

questions.question_text: Dirty places attract _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Dirty places attract flies, mosquitoes, rats, and cockroaches. These pests and insects carry germs that cause diseases. Flies sit on dirty things and carry germs to our food. Mosquitoes breed in stagnant dirty water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dirty places do not attract butterflies, birds, fish, or dolphins. They attract harmful pests like flies, mosquitoes, rats, and cockroaches that spread diseases. This is why it is so important to keep our surroundings clean.

questions.question_text: Rohan noticed that there are many flies and a bad smell near the garbage dump behind his school. This is because _____.

options.text: Flies like to play near schools
Rotting garbage produces bad smell and attracts flies
Schools always have a bad smell
Flies come from the sky when it rains

questions.explanation_correct: Rotting garbage produces a bad smell and attracts flies, mosquitoes, and other pests. As food waste and other garbage decompose, they release gases that smell bad. Flies feed on rotting food and lay eggs in it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flies do not play or come from rain. They are attracted to rotting garbage because they feed on decaying matter. Garbage dumps produce bad smells as waste rots, and this attracts flies and other pests that can spread diseases.

questions.question_text: The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan (Clean India Mission) was started to _____.

options.text: Make India clean by improving sanitation and waste management

questions.explanation_correct: The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was started to make India clean. It aims to improve sanitation (building toilets), manage waste properly, and encourage all citizens to keep their surroundings clean. It is one of India's largest cleanliness campaigns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Swachh Bharat Abhiyan is not about factories, roads, or just flowers. 'Swachh' means clean. It is India's national campaign to promote cleanliness, build toilets, manage garbage properly, and make every citizen responsible for keeping India clean.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an example of wet waste?
questions.explanation_correct: Vegetable peels are wet waste. Wet waste includes food scraps, fruit peels, vegetable peels, leftover food, and tea leaves. Wet waste comes from natural sources and can decompose (break down) on its own.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic bottles, glass jars, and metal cans are dry waste - they do not decompose easily. Vegetable peels are wet waste because they come from plants, contain moisture, and can break down naturally over time.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an example of dry waste?
questions.explanation_correct: A plastic bag is dry waste. Dry waste includes plastic, glass, metal, paper, rubber, and cloth. These materials do not decompose easily in nature and can remain in the environment for hundreds of years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leftover food, fruit peels, and fallen leaves are all wet waste that can decompose naturally. A plastic bag is dry waste because it is made of plastic, which does not break down easily. Plastic pollution is a big environmental problem.

questions.question_text: Anita has two dustbins at home - a green one and a blue one. In which bin should she put banana peels?

options.text: She should throw it on the road
Any bin, it does not matter

questions.explanation_correct: Banana peels should go in the green bin for wet waste. In India, green dustbins are for wet waste (food scraps, peels, leftover food) and blue dustbins are for dry waste (plastic, paper, glass, metal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In India's waste segregation system, green bins are for wet waste and blue bins are for dry waste. Banana peels are wet waste (biodegradable), so they go in the green bin. Throwing waste on the road is wrong and harmful.

questions.question_text: Raj has an empty plastic water bottle. In which dustbin should he put it?
questions.explanation_correct: An empty plastic water bottle is dry waste and should go in the blue dustbin. Plastic does not decompose easily, but it can be collected and recycled into new products. Proper disposal helps the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing plastic in rivers or burying it harms the environment. Plastic is dry waste and should go in the blue bin. From there, it can be sent for recycling. Always dispose of plastic properly to protect our environment.

questions.question_text: Which of these waste items can decompose naturally?
questions.explanation_correct: Fallen leaves and food scraps can decompose naturally. They are biodegradable, which means tiny organisms in the soil can break them down into simpler substances. This process turns them into compost that enriches the soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic bags, glass bottles, and metal tins do not decompose easily - they can remain in the environment for hundreds of years. Fallen leaves and food scraps are the only items that can decompose naturally because they are biodegradable.

questions.question_text: What do the 3Rs stand for?
questions.explanation_correct: The 3Rs stand for Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle. Reduce means using less. Reuse means using things again instead of throwing them away. Recycle means making new things from old materials. The 3Rs help us protect the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 3Rs for protecting the environment are Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), and Recycle (make new from old). These are simple steps everyone can follow to reduce waste and help keep our planet clean.

questions.question_text: Carrying a cloth bag to the market instead of using plastic bags is an example of _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Using a cloth bag instead of plastic bags is an example of 'Reduce'. By choosing cloth bags, we reduce the use of plastic bags, which means less plastic waste in the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using cloth bags is mainly about reducing plastic use. When we choose cloth bags over plastic bags at the shop, we reduce the amount of plastic that enters the environment. This is the 'Reduce' part of the 3Rs.

questions.question_text: Using an old jar to store spices instead of throwing it away is an example of _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Using an old jar to store spices is an example of 'Reuse'. Instead of throwing the jar away, we find a new use for it. This reduces waste because the jar is used again instead of being discarded.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not reducing (using less) or recycling (processing to make new products). It is reusing - finding a new purpose for something old. When we reuse items, we generate less waste and save resources.

questions.question_text: Making new paper from old newspapers at a factory is an example of _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Making new paper from old newspapers is an example of 'Recycle'. Recycling means processing old materials to make new products. Old paper is collected, made into pulp, and used to produce new paper products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not reducing (using less) or reusing (using the same item again). It is recycling - taking old materials and processing them into new products. When old newspapers are recycled into new paper, fewer trees need to be cut down.

questions.question_text: Nisha's mother uses old cotton sarees to make a patchwork quilt. This is an example of _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Making a quilt from old sarees is an example of 'Reuse'. The old cloth is being given a new life as a quilt instead of being thrown away. In India, many families reuse old clothes as dusters, bags, or quilts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is reuse, not reduce or recycle. The old sarees are being used again in a different form (a quilt). This is a creative way to reuse materials and is a common practice in Indian homes.

questions.question_text: Which of these materials can be recycled?
questions.explanation_correct: Paper, plastic, and glass can all be recycled. Old paper can be made into new paper, old plastic can be made into new plastic products, and old glass can be melted and made into new glass items. Recycling saves natural resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cooked food and fruit peels are organic waste that decomposes. Dirty water needs treatment, not recycling. Paper, plastic, and glass are the items that can be recycled at factories to make new products, reducing waste.

questions.question_text: What should you do with a candy wrapper after eating the candy?
questions.explanation_correct: You should throw the candy wrapper in a dustbin. Littering - throwing waste on the road, in rivers, or in parks - is wrong. It makes the place dirty and harms the environment. Always carry your waste to the nearest dustbin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing wrappers on roads, in rivers, or hiding them is all littering. The correct action is to put it in a dustbin. If there is no dustbin nearby, keep the wrapper in your pocket and throw it in a bin later.

questions.question_text: Priya wants to help the environment. Which of these actions should she take?

options.text: Use as many plastic bags as possible
Plant trees, use dustbins, and carry a cloth bag

questions.explanation_correct: Priya should plant trees, use dustbins for waste, and carry a cloth bag to reduce plastic use. These are simple actions that help protect the environment. Planting trees gives oxygen, dustbins keep places clean, and cloth bags reduce plastic waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using more plastic, throwing garbage in parks, and burning plastic all harm the environment. Burning plastic releases toxic fumes. The correct actions are planting trees, using dustbins properly, and reducing plastic by using cloth bags.

questions.question_text: Vikram sees someone throwing garbage into a river near his village. What should he do?

options.text: Start throwing his garbage into the river too
Ignore it, it is not his problem
Politely explain that throwing garbage in the river pollutes the water and harms fish and other animals
Jump into the river to clean it alone

questions.explanation_correct: Vikram should politely explain that throwing garbage in the river is wrong because it pollutes the water. Polluted water harms fish, plants, and animals that live in the river. People who drink or use this water can also get sick.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copying bad behaviour, ignoring problems, or jumping into the river are not good options. Vikram should spread awareness by politely telling the person that river pollution hurts the environment and can make people and animals sick.

questions.question_text: Which of these actions is BEST for the environment?

options.text: Using plastic plates for every meal
Buying new toys every week and throwing old ones away
Using steel plates, carrying a cloth bag, and planting trees

questions.explanation_correct: Using steel plates (reducing plastic waste), carrying a cloth bag (reducing plastic bags), and planting trees (increasing oxygen and greenery) are all excellent actions for the environment. These simple changes make a big difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic plates create waste, buying and throwing toys wastes resources, and leaving lights on wastes electricity. The best actions are using reusable items like steel plates, avoiding plastic with cloth bags, and planting trees.

questions.question_text: It is okay to throw garbage on the road if there is no dustbin nearby.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. It is never okay to throw garbage on the road. If there is no dustbin nearby, you should keep the waste in your bag or pocket and put it in a dustbin when you find one. Littering makes our surroundings dirty and unhealthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not finding a dustbin is not an excuse to litter. You should always keep your waste with you until you find a proper dustbin. Littering on roads makes the area dirty, blocks drains, attracts pests, and harms the environment.

questions.question_text: Plastic is a type of dry waste.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Plastic is dry waste. It does not decompose easily and can stay in the environment for hundreds of years. Plastic should be put in the blue dustbin (dry waste) and sent for recycling whenever possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic is indeed dry waste, also called non-biodegradable waste. It does not rot or break down naturally. This is why plastic pollution is such a big problem - plastic bags, bottles, and wrappers last for hundreds of years in the environment.

questions.question_text: Recycling means throwing things in the dustbin.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Recycling does not just mean throwing things away. Recycling means processing old materials (like paper, plastic, glass) to make new products. For example, old newspapers can be recycled to make new paper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Just throwing things in a dustbin is disposal, not recycling. Recycling is a specific process where old materials are collected, processed, and turned into new products at factories. This saves resources and reduces waste.

questions.question_text: Food scraps and banana peels are wet waste that can decompose naturally.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Food scraps and banana peels are wet waste or biodegradable waste. They can decompose (break down) naturally with the help of tiny organisms in the soil. They can also be composted to make fertiliser for plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food scraps and banana peels are indeed wet waste. They are organic materials that decompose naturally over time. When composted properly, they turn into rich fertiliser that helps plants grow.

questions.question_text: Planting more trees helps keep our environment clean and healthy.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Trees clean the air by absorbing carbon dioxide and releasing oxygen. They also prevent soil erosion, bring rain, provide shelter for birds and animals, and make our surroundings green and beautiful. Planting trees is one of the best things we can do for the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planting trees is one of the best ways to help the environment. Trees purify the air, give us oxygen, hold the soil, bring rain, and provide homes for birds and animals. Everyone should try to plant trees.

questions.question_text: We should always throw waste in a _____, not on the road.
questions.explanation_correct: We should always throw waste in a dustbin. Dustbins keep our surroundings clean by collecting waste properly. Throwing waste on the road is called littering and makes our environment dirty and unhealthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is dustbin. Using dustbins keeps our roads, parks, and neighbourhoods clean. Proper waste disposal prevents diseases and makes our surroundings pleasant to live in.

questions.question_text: Waste that can decompose naturally, like food scraps and leaves, is called _____ waste.
questions.explanation_correct: Waste that can decompose naturally is called wet waste (or biodegradable waste). It includes food scraps, vegetable peels, fruit peels, leftover food, and fallen leaves. Wet waste goes in the green dustbin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is wet. Wet waste includes organic materials like food, peels, and leaves that break down naturally. It is also called biodegradable waste. In India's waste system, wet waste goes in the green bin.

questions.question_text: The 3Rs stand for Reduce, _____, and Recycle.
questions.explanation_correct: The 3Rs are Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle. Reuse means using things again instead of throwing them away. For example, using an old glass jar to store things instead of throwing it away is reusing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Reuse. The 3Rs for protecting our environment are Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), and Recycle (make new from old). Reusing items reduces waste and saves resources.

questions.question_text: The _____ Bharat Abhiyan is India's campaign for keeping the country clean.
questions.explanation_correct: The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan (Clean India Mission) is India's national campaign for cleanliness. 'Swachh' means clean in Hindi. The campaign encourages everyone to keep their surroundings clean and use proper sanitation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Swachh. Swachh Bharat Abhiyan means 'Clean India Mission'. It was launched to promote cleanliness, proper waste management, and sanitation across India.

questions.question_text:
Match the action with the correct 'R':
1. Using both sides of paper  2. Making a pen stand from an old bottle  3. Sending old newspapers to a paper mill
questions.explanation_correct: Using both sides of paper means using less paper, which is Reduce. Making a pen stand from an old bottle gives it a new use, which is Reuse. Sending newspapers to a paper mill to make new paper is Recycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching is: Using both sides of paper = Reduce (you use fewer sheets), Making a pen stand from old bottle = Reuse (using the same item differently), Sending newspapers to paper mill = Recycle (processing old into new).

questions.question_text: Where should we throw waste at school?

options.text: In the dustbin kept in the classroom or corridor

questions.explanation_correct: We should throw waste in the dustbin kept in the classroom or corridor. Schools have dustbins for proper waste disposal. Keeping classrooms and school grounds clean helps everyone study in a healthy and pleasant environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing waste on the playground, in corners, or behind buildings makes the school dirty. Schools provide dustbins for a reason - to collect waste properly. Everyone should use dustbins to keep the school clean and healthy.

questions.question_text: In India, which colour dustbin is used for dry waste?
questions.explanation_correct: In India, the blue dustbin is used for dry waste (plastic, paper, glass, metal). The green dustbin is used for wet waste (food scraps, peels, leaves). Separating waste into these bins is called waste segregation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In India's waste management system, blue bins are for dry waste and green bins are for wet waste. Red bins may be used for hazardous waste in some places. Knowing which bin to use helps in proper waste management.

questions.question_text: Using a steel water bottle instead of buying plastic water bottles every day is an example of _____.

options.text: Reduce - because it reduces plastic waste

questions.explanation_correct: Using a steel water bottle reduces the use of plastic bottles. Every time you refill your steel bottle, you avoid buying and throwing away a plastic bottle. This is the 'Reduce' principle - using less plastic saves the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using a steel bottle actually saves money in the long run and is very helpful for the environment. It reduces plastic waste because you do not buy and throw away plastic bottles. One steel bottle can replace hundreds of plastic bottles.

questions.question_text: How can students help keep their school clean?

options.text: By leaving waste under the desk
By using dustbins, not littering, and keeping classrooms tidy
By bringing more plastic items to school
By waiting for the sweeper to clean everything

questions.explanation_correct: Students can help keep their school clean by using dustbins properly, not littering on the playground or in corridors, and keeping their desks and classrooms tidy. Cleanliness is everyone's responsibility, not just the sweeper's.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaving waste under desks, bringing more plastic, or waiting for others to clean are not helpful. Every student should take responsibility for keeping the school clean by using dustbins and not littering.

questions.question_text: After the school picnic, there was a lot of litter on the ground. What should the students do?

options.text: Leave it there and go home
Pick up the litter and put it in dustbins before leaving
Push the litter into the bushes to hide it

questions.explanation_correct: The students should pick up all the litter and put it in dustbins before leaving. It is important to leave any place as clean as (or cleaner than) we found it. Hiding litter or leaving it behind is irresponsible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaving litter, blaming others, or hiding it are all wrong. Responsible behaviour means cleaning up after ourselves. Students should collect all their waste and dispose of it properly in dustbins before leaving any place.

questions.question_text: A glass bottle takes only a few days to decompose in nature.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Glass does not decompose easily. A glass bottle can take thousands of years to break down in nature. This is why it is important to recycle glass instead of throwing it away carelessly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glass is non-biodegradable, meaning it does not decompose naturally. A glass bottle can remain in the environment for thousands of years. This is why we should recycle glass bottles instead of throwing them into the trash.

questions.question_text: Using old clothes as cleaning rags is an example of reuse.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When we use old clothes as cleaning rags, we are reusing them instead of throwing them away. This gives the old clothes a new purpose and reduces waste. This is a common practice in Indian homes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using old clothes as cleaning rags is indeed reuse. The clothes are not being recycled (processed into new material) or reduced. They are being used again for a different purpose, which is exactly what reuse means.

questions.question_text: Burning plastic is a good way to get rid of plastic waste.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Burning plastic is very harmful. When plastic burns, it releases poisonous gases and fumes that pollute the air and can cause breathing problems and other health issues. Plastic should be recycled, not burned.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning plastic is extremely harmful. It releases toxic chemicals into the air that can cause cancer, breathing problems, and other diseases. Plastic waste should be recycled or disposed of properly at waste management facilities.

questions.question_text: In India, the green dustbin is for _____ waste and the blue dustbin is for dry waste.
questions.explanation_correct: In India, the green dustbin is for wet waste (biodegradable items like food, peels, and leaves) and the blue dustbin is for dry waste (non-biodegradable items like plastic, paper, glass, and metal). Separating waste helps in recycling and composting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is wet. India's waste segregation system uses green bins for wet waste (organic, biodegradable items) and blue bins for dry waste (inorganic, non-biodegradable items). This separation makes waste management more efficient.

questions.question_text: When old newspapers are processed at a factory to make new paper, it is called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: When old newspapers are processed to make new paper, it is called recycling. Recycling converts waste materials into new, useful products. This saves trees (since less new wood is needed) and reduces waste in landfills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is recycling. Recycling is the process of converting old, used materials into new products. When old paper is recycled, it is turned into pulp and made into fresh paper, saving trees and reducing waste.

questions.question_text: We should _____ trees to help clean the air and make our environment green.
questions.explanation_correct: We should plant trees to help clean the air and make our environment green. Trees absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen, which is essential for breathing. They also provide shade, shelter for animals, and make our surroundings beautiful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is plant. Planting trees is one of the simplest and most effective ways to help the environment. Trees purify the air, provide oxygen, prevent soil erosion, and make our world greener and healthier.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases can be caused by dirty surroundings?
questions.explanation_correct: Dengue and malaria are diseases caused by mosquitoes that breed in dirty, stagnant water. Dirty surroundings with garbage and standing water become breeding grounds for mosquitoes, leading to the spread of these dangerous diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colour blindness, near-sightedness, and hearing loss are not caused by dirty surroundings. Dengue and malaria are the diseases that spread through mosquitoes, which breed in dirty, stagnant water found in unclean surroundings.

questions.question_text: Which of these items should NOT be put in the green (wet waste) dustbin?
questions.explanation_correct: A plastic wrapper is dry waste and should NOT be put in the green (wet waste) dustbin. It should go in the blue (dry waste) dustbin. Banana peels, leftover chapati, and tea leaves are all wet waste that can decompose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Banana peels, leftover chapati, and tea leaves are all wet waste that belongs in the green bin. A plastic wrapper is dry waste because plastic does not decompose. It should be placed in the blue dustbin for dry waste.

questions.question_text: Why is plastic pollution a big problem for the environment?

options.text: Because plastic does not decompose easily and harms animals and the environment
Because plastic has a bad colour

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic pollution is a big problem because plastic does not decompose for hundreds of years. It clogs drains, pollutes rivers and oceans, and harms animals who eat it by mistake. Reducing plastic use is very important for our environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The problem with plastic is not about cost, weight, or colour. Plastic stays in the environment for hundreds of years without breaking down. Animals choke on plastic, fish die from eating it, and it pollutes our water and soil.

questions.question_text: Which of these is good for the environment?

options.text: Planting trees and keeping surroundings clean

questions.explanation_correct: Planting trees and keeping surroundings clean are good for the environment. Trees give us oxygen and clean the air. Clean surroundings prevent diseases. Both actions help make our environment healthier and more beautiful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting forests, polluting rivers, and using plastic all harm the environment. Only planting trees and keeping surroundings clean are positive actions that help protect nature and keep us healthy.

questions.question_text: Keeping our surroundings clean is only the job of the municipality and sweepers.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Keeping our surroundings clean is everyone's responsibility. While municipalities and sweepers help maintain public cleanliness, every citizen - including children - must do their part by not littering and keeping their area clean.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cleanliness is not just the job of sweepers or the government. Every person has a responsibility to keep their surroundings clean. Children can help by using dustbins, not littering, and keeping their home and school clean.

questions.question_text: Writing on both sides of a paper before throwing it away is an example of _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Writing on both sides of paper is an example of 'Reduce'. By using both sides, you need fewer sheets of paper, which means less paper is used overall. This reduces waste and saves trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is about reducing - you are reducing the total amount of paper you need. When you write on both sides, you use fewer sheets, which means less paper waste and fewer trees being cut.

questions.question_text: Waste like plastic, glass, and metal that does not decompose easily is called _____ waste or non-biodegradable waste.
questions.explanation_correct: Waste like plastic, glass, and metal that does not decompose easily is called dry waste or non-biodegradable waste. These materials need to be recycled or disposed of properly because they do not break down in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is dry. Dry waste or non-biodegradable waste includes materials like plastic, glass, metal, and rubber that do not decompose naturally. These materials can stay in the environment for hundreds or thousands of years.

questions.question_text: What can we do with kitchen waste like vegetable peels and fruit skins?

options.text: Make compost to use as fertiliser for plants

questions.explanation_correct: Kitchen waste like vegetable peels and fruit skins can be composted. Composting means allowing wet waste to decompose in a compost bin. The result is rich compost (natural fertiliser) that can be used to help plants grow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing waste in rivers, burning, or littering all harm the environment. Composting is the best way to handle kitchen waste. The organic material breaks down and becomes nutrient-rich compost that is excellent for gardening.

questions.question_text: Only adults can follow the 3Rs. Children are too young to help the environment.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Children can definitely follow the 3Rs! Children can reduce by using less paper and plastic, reuse by giving old toys and books to others, and recycle by putting waste in the correct bins. Every small action helps.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children are never too young to help the environment. They can reduce paper and plastic use, reuse old items, and sort waste for recycling. In fact, when children practice the 3Rs, they develop good habits that last a lifetime.

questions.question_text: Which of these is the MOST harmful for the environment?

options.text: Throwing plastic and garbage into a river

questions.explanation_correct: Throwing plastic and garbage into a river is the most harmful action. It pollutes the water, kills fish and other water animals, makes the water unsafe for drinking, and destroys the river ecosystem. All the other options are helpful for the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cloth bags, tree planting, and steel bottles all help the environment. Throwing garbage and plastic into rivers is extremely harmful. It poisons the water, kills aquatic life, and makes the water unsafe for humans and animals.
